Award.AbstractNarration:
With a goal of reducing motor vehicle collisions and fatalities, this project addresses the issue of managing driving privilege in society. The key strategy is to extend the reach of Certified Driver Rehabilitation Specialists (CDRSs) to meet the needs of people with disabilities, seniors in society, and all individuals with medical-impairments affecting their driving capability. The system developed through this project measures the count and duration of CDRS-assisted driving events (or interventions by a supervisory driving instructor). Results from this project may be used to extend surrogate measures of crash safety into the field of driver rehabilitation via the use of in-vehicle data recorders. The detection and quantification of collision avoidance assistance by a certified driving evaluator presents a new capability to test and validate the operation of collision avoidance technologies in the automotive industry.

Applications of driver monitoring technologies from the commercial driving industry to driver training and evaluation presents a potential for driver licensing to be defined across evaluation sites. Through the integration of new vehicle technologies into the standard of practice, barriers of entry to the profession can be mitigated for myriad trained professionals who are eligible to enter the field of driver rehabilitation. Automated report generation to quantify driving capability based on driver monitoring technologies may streamline business processes for current professionals and reduce the tension imposed upon the patient-physician relationship due to mandatory physician reporting laws.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Team Navity conducted 111 customer discovery interviews over the I-Corps Curriculum period, to evaluate the value proposition of the NAViSection System. This system was designed to automatically document every instance when a driving evaluator assists drivers with steering or braking during a driving session (e.g. by driving schools or driver rehabilitation programs). The driver rehabilitation and driving school professionals communicated a strong interest in the capability of the NAViSection System. Channels to support the distribution of this technology already exist across the US due to the market of vehicle modifications for people with disabilities.

 

Driver rehabilitation specialists appreciate the opportunity for data collection to reinforce their licensing recommendations for self-assurance, more than the ability of the data to support their position in the face of a dismissive/argumentative client. In relation to third-party payer sources, the state vocational rehabilitation office could view data from the NAViSection System as a metric to justify whether or not additional training sessions are justifiable using state funds. Driving instructors have lower motivation to make use of data for any reporting responsibilities to the state, but they inherently need more ways to communicate/transition the training of teens to their parents or family members.

 

For both settings, in-vehicle data collection presents a compelling opportunity to address the long-term issue regarding driving ability amongst vulnerable populations (e.g. teen, medically-impaired, and older drivers). Products and services from the telematics industry provide continuous data recording capabilities in most vehicles, which may facilitate the needs for performance monitoring over time. In this sense, the NAViSection System would provide a platform to automate data analysis and integrate telematics data with the documentation of near crash events and recommendations to improve driver capability whenever possible. Policy reform and regulatory efforts could advance data recording to profile teen driving performance with graduated driver licensing laws, but older drivers would strongly oppose mandatory laws due to their political engagement and financial resources to lobby for their interests. The prospective position of physicians has not been assessed regarding the use of in-vehicle data recorders to supplement their recommendations under mandatory physician reporting laws.

 

To expand the impact of the NAViSection System, broader commercial efforts could advance the training of novice pilots by dual-control planes to demonstrate competency and independent control of aircraft. A greater contribution to safe driving may include the unique opportunity for testing collision avoidance systems (automatic steering and braking assistance) in the automotive industry. By using advanced cars with integrated sensors as evaluation vehicles, it is possible to compare the evaluator’s steering and braking assistance to the vehicle’s software outputs, which state when to apply automated steering or braking. The vehicle would not actually engage collision avoidance systems, but would function like a driving simulator on real roads, with real drivers, in a real car. As a result, the automotive partners would achieve real-world testing on public roads without liability for crashes or the expenses of fuel and paid drivers to complete testing on public roads.

 

Over the remaining months of the I-Corps Teams award, Navity was featured as a technology preview from the University of Pittsburgh at the annual demo day held by AlphaLab, a business accelerator in Pittsburgh.
